Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I was walking home from school with my step-brother, Jamie, like we always did. We joked about homework and what we’d eat for dinner, but I kept an eye on the cars and made sure he stayed on the inside of the sidewalk. That’s what Mom always said—look out for each other, especially since Jamie’s still getting used to the neighborhood. As we passed the community center, I remembered I needed to drop off my mail-in ballot. Jamie waited by the door while I went inside. The poll worker looked at my envelope and frowned. “This signature is smudged. Please re-sign it so your vote counts,” she said, sliding it back to me. I hesitated, remembering the instructions: never sign twice, or the ballot could be disqualified. But the poll worker insisted, and I could see Jamie through the glass, shifting from foot to foot, looking nervous. I felt torn—should I trust the official and re-sign, or stick to the rules I’d read? And what if Jamie got anxious or wandered off while I was stuck here, wrestling with this choice? My heart pounded as I stood between my duty as a voter and my responsibility as a step-sibling, unsure which to put first.
